Expectation1: Communicate any challenges or concerns promptly to the mentor.
Situation1: A technical hurdle is preventing the mentee from advancing on the current project.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: Officials ask voters with last names A–M to move to a newly opened line, even though the original line is moving faster.
Story: I stood in the snaking line at the polling station, my phone buzzing in my pocket. My mentor’s last message echoed in my mind: “Let me know immediately if you hit any roadblocks.” I had, in fact, hit a major one—a technical glitch that threatened to derail my entire project. I knew I should text her right away, but the election official’s voice cut through my thoughts: “If your last name starts with A through M, please move to the new line.” My last name started with B. The new line looked longer and slower, but the instructions were clear. I hesitated, torn. If I stayed put, I’d be ignoring the official’s directions, but if I moved, I’d lose precious time to update my mentor and possibly miss her window to help. My chest tightened as I weighed the pressure to be a responsible mentee against my duty as a rule-abiding voter. Both roles demanded immediate action, but I couldn’t see a way to satisfy them both at once.
